title: Easy and Efficient Cryo-FIB Workflow for Cryo-TEM Sample Preparation
content: Cryo-transmission electron microscopy (cryo-TEM) of frozen-hydrated biological samples can provide near-native high-resolution structural information of tissues, bacteria, cells, and the macromolecules within [1]. For electrons to transmit the frozen biological sample, the thickness of the sample must be a few hundred nanometers [1]. Focused ion beam with a cryo-stage (cryo-FIB) has been utilized to produce the thin samples [2]. Generally, the plunge- or high-pressure frozen samples are imaged at first by a fluorescence microscope equipped with a cooling stage to determine regions for lamella-milling. Then, the sample is transferred to the cryo-FIB (typically combined with scanning electron microscope column). The areas determined with the fluorescence microscope are identified with the SEM and milled with the FIB. After producing lamellae, a TEM grid with the lamellae is transferred to the cryo-TEM, and imaging the lamellae are performed.
